newsitem.title: USA: U.S. fires more missiles at Iraq targets.
newsitem.headline: U.S. fires more missiles at Iraq targets.

text.p: The United States on Tuesday night launched a second cruise missile attack on Iraq, firing 17 Tomahawks from a U.S. submarine and three surface warships to further damage air defences in southern Iraq.

The Pentagon and White House said the repeat strike was authorised by President Bill Clinton and was made against a number of targets that were not completely damaged in an attack by 27 missiles earlier on Tuesday.
The $1.2 million Tomahawk cruise missiles were fired from the ships in the Gulf at military targets such as radars in southern Iraq early on Wednesday morning Iraq time.
Eight missiles were fired by the destroyer Russell, five by the destroyer Laboon, two by the destroyer Hewitt and two by the Los Angeles Class attack submarine Jefferson City.
"This is what we call a mop-up operation," Defence Department spokesman Ken Bacon told reporters at a briefing.

Defence officials said an attack by 27 missiles fired from two warships and B-52 bombers earlier on Tuesday had not done the damage expected against all Iraqi missile defence targets in the southern part of the country.
The unilateral missile attacks were launched after Saddam had reportedly ignored demands to cease an assault on Kurds in northern Iraq and withdraw his troops.

Bacon said Clinton authorised the strikes to supress air defences over southern Iraq and provide a greater margin of safety for U.S. and allied pilots who will police an expanded "no-fly" zone over southern Iraq beginning at noon on Wednesday in Baghdad (0800 GMT).
The new southern no-fly zone extends north from Iraq's southern border all the way to the outskirts of Baghdad.
"It (the second strike) required additional approval and he (Clinton) granted that this afternoon," the spokesman said.

"It is an effort to go in and assure that we have done everything possible to supress air defences before we start enforcing the expanded no-fly zone ... we want to guarantee that our pilots have every opportunity to fly safely."
But Bacon said in response to questions that, "in the defence business, I don't think there is any such thing as impunity" for pilots.
